More rabies cases in northern Thailand

Dr. Thawichai of the 9th Disease Prevention and Control Office said on the 9th of this month that rabies infections have increased in the northeast of Thailand in recent months, with a total of 74 cases.
So far this year (October 2018 - September 2019) 74 people have tested positive for rabies in the northeastern provinces of Surin and Briram, with 67 and 7 people respectively.
Everyone has been vaccinated against rabies in the past.
The doctor is urging people to get their pets vaccinated against rabies and to avoid contact with saliva from any animals they suspect may be infected.
Rabies can be transmitted from cats, bats, and other animals besides dogs.
It is almost 100% fatal once a person is infected and shows symptoms, but vaccination before symptoms can prevent death.

Fujitsu develops system to prevent accidents caused by leaving the steering wheel unattended, tests it on its own vehicles | Chubu Economic Newspaper: Economic news from Aichi, Gifu, Mie, and Shizuoka Prefectures

FUJI (Chiryu Head Office) which manufactures and sells electronic component installation robots and machine tools has started developing a system to prevent "abandonment" such as children being left in cars.
The system works by installing motion sensors in the car that detect when people are moving, and then sends notifications to phones and chat apps.
They are currently conducting a proof of concept with their own shuttle.
While accidents happen when parents leave their children behind, we must protect our children's safety.
Currently, they are conducting a proof of concept using two of their own vehicles for the after-school English conversation program for children, Terakoya Sanku, which they operate in Chiryu City.
Three human sensors that detect human movement from the temperature difference between the person and the surroundings are installed in the ceiling of the car.
If the vehicle is parked with the engine off and the doors locked, and if it detects movement after a certain amount of time, it will automatically send a warning notification.
By coordinating the state and information of the engine and door, it is possible to prevent false detection to the extent possible.
The alert notification is sent through the cloud.
You can call the number you registered in advance or display it on the chat of your computer or smartphone.
You can register multiple addresses and they take care to avoid mistakes like forgetting to send it.
The trial will continue until the end of February.
"During the experiment, we also saw issues outside of the system," said Kanaya Ichikawa, head of the second section of the Innovation Promotion Department.
For example, they were able to pick up on various challenges related to school buses, such as designing an environment that allows drivers to concentrate on driving.
"We're going to expand the solution," he said, with conviction.
The development of the anti-abandonment system was sparked by a series of accidents involving abandoned school buses across the country.
From employees with young children, I have received suggestions on what can be done to ensure the safety of children.

They decided to develop the technology, using the know-how they had gained from their FA (Factory Automation) related business, such as using IoT (Internet of Things) and sensors for information management.
The Fujitsu system is easy to use.
The sensors can be installed by just attaching them to the ceiling with pins.
The ease of retrofitting to the shuttle buses lowers the barrier to entry and allows for widespread adoption.
In the future, they will be looking to collaborate with kindergartens and nurseries to develop the product.

[Opinion] Echizen Town is making an ending note and distributing it to the residents who want it.

Last year, when he published a "funeral handbook" that covered all the necessary procedures and forms for writing a will, as well as genealogical charts, he found that many people came to him to ask for help.

In various parts of the prefecture, there are also regular seminars on how to write the ending note and how to prepare for the end of life, and it seems that "end-of-life activities" have become a well-established part of the local culture.
Echizen's ending note is 35 pages.

Chapter 5 begins with a review of your life story, and you write down your current health status, financial situation, future care needs, wishes for end-of-life care, and preferences for funeral and burial.
There are also sections for things you want to do in the rest of your life and messages to people you care about.
It’s tempting to say there are 35 pages, but you don’t need to fill every page.
What do you want to be remembered for, by your family and others?
The point is to make it clear what the purpose is.
There are many different types of notebooks available at bookstores and elsewhere, and you can start writing in them at any time.
In terms of job hunting, the term "end of life" was born in 2009.
Two years later, in 2011, the Great East Japan Earthquake occurred.
Many people have come to realize that "death comes suddenly," and there are more people who are preparing for their own end and the end of life.
It's been over a decade since then.
The COVID-19 pandemic that has swept the world is still not over.
Prices have risen due to the Russian invasion of Ukraine, and electricity bills have skyrocketed this winter.
On the other hand, wages have not risen enough to match current high inflation, and many people are struggling.
On the other hand, in the past, funeral expenses, care expenses, and the management of graves could be shared by siblings and relatives, but nowadays, it is rare to have only one child.
There is also the dilemma that while life expectancy has increased significantly in the past few years, the risk of dementia and need for care increases with age.
We should remember that the fact that the end of life is not a temporary phenomenon but a permanent one is also related to the rise of social anxiety.
Either way, no one wants to put their partner or children through unnecessary stress.
"Dying with dignity" is a popular phrase in the end-of-life note, but it shouldn't be too much of a solo effort.
Wishes and preferences should not be kept secret, but should be discussed with family members and prepared for calmly.

A self-published book titled "Dear Prime Minister, The Breakwater of Life" by Tōjinbō, edited by NPO organization "Heart-touching Collection Editorial Office"
"Dear Prime Minister, 'The Breakwater of Life' from Tōjinbō"  I published the 10th book with this title.
The national newspapers have picked up the story and we have had many letters from readers.

The purpose of publishing this book is to share the contents of the "social and structural" environmental problems that are the cause of suicide in Japan, as heard directly from those who have attempted suicide, and to create a "society that is good to live in" with the hope that everyone will share in this.

We have been patrolling the waterfront of Tōjinbō, Fukui Prefecture, which is called a suicide spot, for 18 years and 10 months to prevent suicide, and we continue to support activities to discover and protect suicidal people and support them until they can restart their lives.
This letter sets out seven key points for the Prime Minister on the national policies needed to prevent suicide, following the issues raised by 784 people (2/6) who have been supported to date.
(1) Suicide prevention activities are "life saving" activities.
(2) Behind suicide, there are accumulated "human rights violations."
(3) Suicide victims are victims of societal and structural organized crime.
(4) The administration treats citizens living outside its jurisdiction as “outsiders” and gives them the cold shoulder.
(5) Depression and other mental disorders are medicated and treated as “accidents” even if they commit suicide.
(6) "Duty of care" to suicide hotspots forgotten as commercialism takes over.
(7) The parts of the teachings of new religious groups that cannot be scientifically proven are lies, and the behavior of threatening the future and demanding money is extortion.
Religious groups that engage in these fraudulent and extortionate practices should be exposed and shunned.

It's a really sad thing.
Everyone is who they are.
I hope that we can live in a society where we can enjoy our own lives.
I felt respect and gratitude towards all the staff who put their heart into helping those who were carrying the pain of wanting to die.
I think this is a very demanding activity for both the mind and the body, but please continue to call out and let us know if you are okay.
Thank you.

Introducing the pioneers of plant research. Also included are materials collected from Mount Hayachine. Exhibition planned by the City Comprehensive Cultural Property Center [Hakama] | Iwanichi Online Iwate Nippo

An exhibition titled "People who introduced the flowers of Hayachine - A brief history of Hayachine plant research" which features the pioneers who laid the foundation for plant research on Hayachine, which is known as a treasure trove of alpine plants, is being held at the City General Cultural Property Center in Ohasama, Hanamaki City until the 12th.

The book collects 124 items of materials, including valuable specimens collected by previous researchers, and introduces the footprints of previous researchers involved in the study of plants in Hayachine Mountain.

The study of plants in Hayachine Mountain began with the Russian botanist Karl Johann Maximovich (1827-1911), who came to Japan in the late Edo period, and Sugawa Chonosuke (1842-1925), who collected plants under Maximovich's guidance.
Unable to freely walk around the country as a foreigner, Maksimovic asked Sugawa to collect the data and continued his research for three years, based in Yokohama and Nagasaki.
Sugawara continued to support Maximo's research after his return to Japan, which led to the discovery of the native cherry blossoms, sanguisorba, and Japanese mountain ash.

Later, modern botanist Makino Fujitaro (1862-1957) published "Bistorta hayachinensis" in 1903 (Meiji 36) based on the collection of local researchers, and "Kobanotsumeke" and "Nambutranos" in 1905 (Meiji 38), and "Katoakobebe" in 1907
From the exhibit materials, it is clear that many researchers have identified valuable alpine plants.

The book also introduces the work of others, such as Sugimura Masanosuke (1874-1948), who was a botanist and accompanied the survey of natural monuments in 1927, and Tamakawa Shichiro (1914-1988), who worked as a museum curator at the Hasama Mountain Museum in Hasama Town and also contributed to the publication of "The Plants of Mt.

"There is a lot of research and human connections behind the names of each plant on Mount Hayachine," said Yoshida, a researcher at the center. "We can trace the connections between researchers from local areas to the whole country."

The exhibition is divided into four chapters, with the first chapter focusing on the beliefs and history of Mount Fuji, and the second chapter focusing on the geological features of Mount Fuji as seen through the research of Heinrich Edmund Naumann (1854-1927), a German geologist who laid the foundation for Japanese geology.

Idlib province in northwestern Syria, which was hit by a major earthquake, 9 a.m. (Photo provided by local residents and shared)

(Gaziantep, Turkey) A massive earthquake centered in southern Turkey has killed more than 21,000 people in both Turkey and neighboring Syria, authorities in both countries said on the ninth day of the disaster.
Rescue efforts to pull survivors from collapsed buildings and other debris in the bitter cold have become more difficult as time passes.
In the affected areas, the search for survivors continued.
The United Nations said on Friday that it had delivered aid across the Turkish border into the northwestern Syrian province of Idlib for the first time since the earthquake hit six days ago.
Idlib province was the last stronghold of anti-regime rebels fighting against Assad's rule in Syria, and there were concerns that it would fall without international support.
Rescue efforts are continuing in both countries, using heavy machinery, but are facing difficulties.
Many people are still buried under the rubble, and the death toll is likely to rise.
Turkish authorities say they have confirmed 17,674 deaths in Turkey.
The disaster has claimed more than 3,000 lives in Syria, making it the deadliest earthquake in Turkey since 1999, when more than 17,000 people were killed.

Renewable energy introduction and goals discussed at Amami Airport 2nd decarbonization promotion council meeting | Society & Economy | Nankai Daily News
Promotion Council for Discussion on Decarbonization of Amami Airport = 9th, Kasari, Amami City

The "Amami Airport Decarbonization Promotion Council" (Chairman: Takashi Ando, Chief of the Construction Section of the Ōshima Subprefecture Construction Department, 13 members) which is composed of the prefecture and airlines that use the airport, held its second meeting at the airport on the 9th.
All members, including online members, attended.
The exchange of opinions was focused on setting the goal of decarbonization and the introduction of renewable energy, with solar power generation as the main subject.

The Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism has set a total goal of reducing greenhouse gas emissions at each airport by 46% (compared to 13 fiscal year) by 2050, with the aim of achieving carbon neutrality by 2050.
In response, the council held its first meeting last November and is aiming to develop a plan ahead of other airports on the other six islands in the prefecture.
The second meeting, as at the first, was closed to the public except for the opening.
According to Ando, who responded to the press after the meeting, the group confirmed the amount of greenhouse gas emissions at the airport.
The two countries have been working on negotiations based on the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' guidelines to set goals and introduce renewable energy.
According to the distribution material, the CO2 emissions from the same airport facilities and vehicles in the reference year of 2013 were 1476 (excluding aircraft).

Of these, seven facilities, including airport terminal buildings, account for about 90% of the emissions, including lighting and air conditioning, with airport lights and airport vehicles accounting for 84 and 71 grams, respectively.
The council will discuss reducing the emissions of these facilities and vehicles.
"We are at a crossroads," said Ando, "and the direction of the committee is in agreement, so I would like to firmly compile the interim report."
In the future, the third meeting will hear opinions on the interim report, and the fourth meeting will hear opinions on the final report, and then the plan will be formulated.
"Sakasama Real Estate" opens Okinawa Nirai District Office to bring people to the island, inviting people to rent houses | Society & Economy | Ryukyu Shimpo
Opening event to deepen understanding of "reverse real estate" at talk session, famous town on the 8th.

[Okinoerabu General Affairs Bureau] The Okinoerabu branch office of the real estate web service "Sakasama Real Estate" which visualizes the thoughts of people who want to challenge to rent out vacant houses and shops, and collects landlords, opened on the 8th at the famous community space "etaku" in China-cho.
The operating company explained the service's details in a talk session.
"If we can do this on Okinera-bu Island, we can bring people in and create a flow throughout the island," said Tsukinoba's representative director, Okubo Shingo.

SakaSama Real Estate works in reverse of the normal real estate process, by displaying information about people who want to rent and contacting landlords, and if they agree, they can sign the contract themselves.
As a proof of concept experiment to uncover potential vacant homes and build relationships through vacant homes, the service was launched in June 2020 by On-C Co. Ltd. (headquarters Mie Prefecture).
The opening of the branch office is the seventh in the region.
It is the first time in the country for an island.
The event was attended by about 20 people, including staff from O-co and Tsuginoba, the town offices of Wakabayashi and Shimane, and local residents.

"As the movement to bring people from outside the island has become more active, I thought that if we could utilize empty houses and empty stores, the town and the island would become more lively," Okubo said, explaining the background of the branch office's establishment.
"I want to connect with people who have property on the island or who want to do something and help them in any way I can to get that going," he said.

"We need to take care of each and every vacant house, and we need to talk with the locals about what they want to do with the area, who they want to come in and work with, and what criteria they want to use," said Mizutani Gakushi, the representative of On-cho Co.
"The more people connect with each other, the more information will come in," he said, calling for islanders to participate in discussions and to cooperate in providing information.

I used the SIM free iPhone 7s.

At first, I didn't know how to do it after arriving in Korea and pointing my SIM, so I asked a woman at the SK counter at Gimpo Airport (go to settings > mobile communication > communication options and turn data roaming ON) and she helped me out.
The instructions that came with the product didn't seem to matter much...?
However, the Gimpo airport area has poor reception, so I had to hold onto 3G for a long time.
It became 4G when it was released.
I had some really heavy downloads in the evening and at night, but looking back I probably hit the daily limit of a few hundred MB.
it's better than i thought.

I had been using a Softbank Z4 for 2 years, and had it unlocked and was using it on Ymobile, but when the Z4 started to give me trouble I was looking for a used Xperia to buy, but then I found this phone and bought it, which is a new phone that can be used as a prepaid phone.
I was worried that I wouldn't be able to use it because I was using a mobile Suica, but it worked fine.
Size, weight, silver, and I think I bought it because it looked like an iPhone 6.

Since I don’t use GAME, the processing speed is the same as Z4, and I have the impression that it’s a bit faster.  In the review, it was said that the fingerprint recognition was slow, but I have the impression that it takes a bit of time to recognize it, so I use the face recognition.
I thought it was like an iPhone and it was awesome. I also upgraded my Android to Ver9 and I was satisfied with my purchase.
things i like  i wish it was smaller  no strap hole  *it works with a case with a strap hole  not waterproof tested  a bit heavy  i've only used it a little bit but i'm satisfied  i recommend it
